elements.content: A series of three-dimensional lanthanide coordination compounds with rutile topology, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4), and Tm (5), CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide), have been synthesized under mild conditions. They are isomorphous and crystallize in monoclinic symmetry with space group P21/n. The structure can be considered to be built up from metallic 6-connected and organic 3-connected building units with vertex symbol (4·4·4·4·64·64). These lanthanide coordination compounds possess 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels along the [100] direction, and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels along the [011] and [01̅1] direction, respectively. The fluorescent, water, and methanol adsorption properties of these compounds are studied, and the results reveal that they could be potentially utilized as multifunctional materials.
elements.clean_text: A series of three-dimensional lanthanide coordination compounds with rutile topology, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4), and Tm (5), CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N'-dimethylformamide), have been synthesized under mild conditions. They are isomorphous and crystallize in monoclinic symmetry with space group P21/n. The structure can be considered to be built up from metallic 6-connected and organic 3-connected building units with vertex symbol (4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅64⋅64). These lanthanide coordination compounds possess 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels along the [100] direction, and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels along the [011] and [01̅1] direction, respectively. The fluorescent, water, and methanol adsorption properties of these compounds are studied, and the results reveal that they could be potentially utilized as multifunctional materials.

elements.content: A series of three-dimensional (3-D) lanthanide coordination compounds, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Tm, CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide), have been synthesized under mild conditions. These open frameworks possess 3-D interconnecting pores and rutile topology with a vertex symbol of (4·4·4·4·64·64).
elements.clean_text: A series of three-dimensional (3-D) lanthanide coordination compounds, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Tm, CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N'-dimethylformamide), have been synthesized under mild conditions. These open frameworks possess 3-D interconnecting pores and rutile topology with a vertex symbol of (4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅64⋅64).

elements.content: In recent years, much attention has been paid to the research of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), which have unusual topologies and potential applications, such as catalysis and ion exchange. In order to design and synthesize novel MOFs with specific structures and properties, much work is being focused on choosing the favored geometry and function of metal ions and organic ligands. Lanthanide ions, as functional metal-center ions with optical and magnetic properties, show a wide range of potential technological applications, such as optoelectronic devices and fluoroimmunoassays. And owing to their higher coordination number and more flexible coordination geometry, lanthanide metals should produce novel structures with charming topologies different from transition metals. Therefore, more and more attention has been paid to research exploring novel lanthanide coordination compounds. As known, organic ligands containing O- or N-donors are better choices to synthesize MOFs. As an organic ligand containing O-donors, cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid (H3CTC), which is a saturated ring analogue to 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), has more coordination fashion than the rigid ring carboxylate, and interesting porous structures are anticipated. H3CTC has been used to synthesize a series of transition metals coordination compounds. Compared to transition metals coordination compounds with the CTC organic ligand, only one coordination ligand consisting of the lanthanide metals and CTC ligand, [Er(CTC)(H2O)2]·2.5H2O, which is synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, has been reported. In this paper, we employed a liquid diffusion method under mild conditions to synthesize a series of three-dimensional (3-D) lanthanide coordination compounds, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4), and Tm (5)), with 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels viewed along the [100] direction and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels viewed along the [011] and [01̅1] direction, respectively. In these structures, the dinuclear metal center, each of which is nine-coordinated, connected with six CTC ligands is regarded as a six-connected node and each CTC ligand connected with three dinuclear metal centers is considered as a three-connected node. From the view of the topology, these 3-D frameworks are constructed by six- and three-connected nodes and exhibit rutile topology. Additionally, the fluorescent, water, and methanol adsorption properties as well as the thermal stability of these compounds are investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, much attention has been paid to the research of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which have unusual topologies and potential applications, such as catalysis and ion exchange. In order to design and synthesize novel MOFs with specific structures and properties, much work is being focused on choosing the favored geometry and function of metal ions and organic ligands. Lanthanide ions, as functional metal-center ions with optical and magnetic properties, show a wide range of potential technological applications, such as optoelectronic devices and fluoroimmunoassays. And owing to their higher coordination number and more flexible coordination geometry, lanthanide metals should produce novel structures with charming topologies different from transition metals. Therefore, more and more attention has been paid to research exploring novel lanthanide coordination compounds. As known, organic ligands containing O- or N-donors are better choices to synthesize MOFs. As an organic ligand containing O-donors, cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid (H3CTC), which is a saturated ring analogue to 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), has more coordination fashion than the rigid ring carboxylate, and interesting porous structures are anticipated. H3CTC has been used to synthesize a series of transition metals coordination compounds. Compared to transition metals coordination compounds with the CTC organic ligand, only one coordination ligand consisting of the lanthanide metals and CTC ligand, [Er(CTC)(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O, which is synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, has been reported. In this paper, we employed a liquid diffusion method under mild conditions to synthesize a series of three-dimensional (3-D) lanthanide coordination compounds, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4), and Tm (5)), with 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels viewed along the [100] direction and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels viewed along the [011] and [01̅1] direction, respectively. In these structures, the dinuclear metal center, each of which is nine-coordinated, connected with six CTC ligands is regarded as a six-connected node and each CTC ligand connected with three dinuclear metal centers is considered as a three-connected node. From the view of the topology, these 3-D frameworks are constructed by six- and three-connected nodes and exhibit rutile topology. Additionally, the fluorescent, water, and methanol adsorption properties as well as the thermal stability of these compounds are investigated.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were reagent grade or better and were used without further purification. Rare earth nitrate salts (M(NO3)3·nH2O) were prepared by dissolving rare earth oxides with 6 M HNO3, while adding a bit of H2O2 for Tb4O7, then evaporated at 100 °C until the crystallite formed. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a LS55 luminescence spectrometer. The elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded (400−4000 cm−1 region) on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under oxygen with a heating rate of 20 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

All chemicals purchased were reagent grade or better and were used without further purification. Rare earth nitrate salts (M(NO3)3⋅nH2O) were prepared by dissolving rare earth oxides with 6 M HNO3, while adding a bit of H2O2 for Tb4O7, then evaporated at 100 °C until the crystallite formed. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a LS55 luminescence spectrometer. The elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded (400-4000 cm-1 region) on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under oxygen with a heating rate of 20 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer.

elements.content: Because of the same process of preparing compounds 1−5, the compound 1 is described in detail. A DMF (10 mL) and H2O (5 mL) mixed-solution containing Tb(NO3)3·nH2O (50 mg, 0.12 mmol) and H3CTC (10 mg, 0.05 mmol) was placed in a 20 mL test tube, and 0.5 mL of DMF solution containing triethylamine (0.05 mL) was put in a small vial. The vial was sealed with a stopper which had been pierced with a pinprick to allow slow diffusion of the contents. This vial was placed in the larger test tube, and then the test tube was left at 4 °C for 14 days and at room temperature for 35 days, and colorless crystals of compound 1 were collected (yield: 61% base on Tb). If the test tube was not left at 4 °C before removing it to room temperature, hardly any crystals formed. Main IR absorption bands (cm−1): 3427s, 2930w, 2868w, 1658m, 1595m, 1539s, 1427s, 1113m, 1061m, 783m, 681s, 581m. For compounds 2−5, yield: 71%, 68%, 63%, and 69%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Tb(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) (1)

Because of the same process of preparing compounds 1-5, the compound 1 is described in detail. A DMF (10 mL) and H2O (5 mL) mixed-solution containing Tb(NO3)3⋅nH2O (50 mg, 0.12 mmol) and H3CTC (10 mg, 0.05 mmol) was placed in a 20 mL test tube, and 0.5 mL of DMF solution containing triethylamine (0.05 mL) was put in a small vial. The vial was sealed with a stopper which had been pierced with a pinprick to allow slow diffusion of the contents. This vial was placed in the larger test tube, and then the test tube was left at 4 °C for 14 days and at room temperature for 35 days, and colorless crystals of compound 1 were collected (yield: 61% base on Tb). If the test tube was not left at 4 °C before removing it to room temperature, hardly any crystals formed. Main IR absorption bands (cm-1): 3427s, 2930w, 2868w, 1658m, 1595m, 1539s, 1427s, 1113m, 1061m, 783m, 681s, 581m. For compounds 2-5, yield: 71%, 68%, 63%, and 69%.

elements.content: The intensity data were collected on a Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature in the ω−2θ scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the data using the SADABS program. These structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL program. These crystallographic data were summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles of the five complexes were listed in Table and , respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

The intensity data were collected on a Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature in the ω-2θ scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the data using the SADABS program. These structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL program. These crystallographic data were summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles of the five complexes were listed in Table  and , respectively.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, elemental analysis, and TGA analysis performed on the lanthanide compounds 1−5 reveal that they are identical in structure with the formula M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4), and Tm (5)). Therefore, we describe and discuss the compound 1 representatively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the structure of 1 possesses a 3-D framework. As shown in Figure , the fundamental building unit contains two nine-coordinated Tb ions, two CTC ligands, two coordinated DMF molecules, two coordinated H2O molecules, two free DMF molecules, and two free H2O molecules. Tb1 (M3+) is coordinated with six oxygen atoms (O1−O6) from three bidentate carboxylate groups of the CTC ligands, one oxygen atom (O4A) from a bridging bidentate carboxylate group of the CTC ligand, one oxygen atom (O7) from a coordinated DMF molecule, and one oxygen atom (O1W) from a coordinated H2O molecule. The carboxylic O−Tb bonds are in the range of 2.378−2.591 Å, the Tb−ODMF band is 2.438 Å, and Tb−Owt is 2.428 Å, all of which are comparable to those reported for other terbium−oxygen donor coordination compounds. The compound 1 has a relatively large 3-D aperture, 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels along the [100] direction (Figure a) and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels along the [011] and [01̅1] direction (Figure b,c), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, elemental analysis, and TGA analysis performed on the lanthanide compounds 1-5 reveal that they are identical in structure with the formula M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4), and Tm (5)). Therefore, we describe and discuss the compound 1 representatively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the structure of 1 possesses a 3-D framework. As shown in Figure , the fundamental building unit contains two nine-coordinated Tb ions, two CTC ligands, two coordinated DMF molecules, two coordinated H2O molecules, two free DMF molecules, and two free H2O molecules. Tb1 (M3+) is coordinated with six oxygen atoms (O1-O6) from three bidentate carboxylate groups of the CTC ligands, one oxygen atom (O4A) from a bridging bidentate carboxylate group of the CTC ligand, one oxygen atom (O7) from a coordinated DMF molecule, and one oxygen atom (O1W) from a coordinated H2O molecule. The carboxylic O-Tb bonds are in the range of 2.378-2.591 Å, the Tb-ODMF band is 2.438 Å, and Tb-Owt is 2.428 Å, all of which are comparable to those reported for other terbium-oxygen donor coordination compounds. The compound 1 has a relatively large 3-D aperture, 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels along the [100] direction (Figure a) and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels along the [011] and [01̅1] direction (Figure b,c), respectively.

elements.clean_text: 2  The channels of compound Tb(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) viewed along the [100] (a), [011] (b), and [01̅1] (c) directions (Tb, green; O, red; C, gray). H atoms were omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The further insight into the structure and topology of this 3-D framework can be helpful to deeply understand the coordination function of this MOF. In this framework, two terbium atoms of dinuclear metal center have central symmetry, and each of them connects with seven O atoms belonging to four different carboxylate groups of CTC ligand. Each metal carboxylate cluster, which is made up of a dinuclear metal center and six coordinating carboxylate groups of CTC ligand, is described as a distort octahedron and regarded as an inorganic secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure a). As an organic SBU, each CTC ligand bonds to three metal carboxylate clusters with distorted trigonal geometry (Figure b). It is more distinct to study the topology of the framework when the metal carboxylate cluster is regarded as a six-connected node and the saturated ring of the CTC ligand is regarded as a three-connected node. Six-connected inorganic SBUs and three-connected organic SBUs correspond to Ti coordinating six O atoms and O coordinating three Ti atoms in the rutile net, respectively. And the framework is represented by the topology of rutile (Figure c). On the basis of the simplification principle, the topology of rutile is shown in Figure c, and its Schläfli symbol is (4·4·4·4·64·64).
elements.clean_text: The further insight into the structure and topology of this 3-D framework can be helpful to deeply understand the coordination function of this MOF. In this framework, two terbium atoms of dinuclear metal center have central symmetry, and each of them connects with seven O atoms belonging to four different carboxylate groups of CTC ligand. Each metal carboxylate cluster, which is made up of a dinuclear metal center and six coordinating carboxylate groups of CTC ligand, is described as a distort octahedron and regarded as an inorganic secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure a). As an organic SBU, each CTC ligand bonds to three metal carboxylate clusters with distorted trigonal geometry (Figure b). It is more distinct to study the topology of the framework when the metal carboxylate cluster is regarded as a six-connected node and the saturated ring of the CTC ligand is regarded as a three-connected node. Six-connected inorganic SBUs and three-connected organic SBUs correspond to Ti coordinating six O atoms and O coordinating three Ti atoms in the rutile net, respectively. And the framework is represented by the topology of rutile (Figure c). On the basis of the simplification principle, the topology of rutile is shown in Figure c, and its Schläfli symbol is (4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅64⋅64).

elements.content: The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1−5 are shown in Figure . The emission group of compound 1 is in the range of 460−660 nm (λex = 235 nm), which can be attributed to the terbium ion, corresponding to 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, and 3), and free H3CTC ligand, respectively. The emission peak at 523 nm of compound 1 should be related to the emission of ligand-to-metal-charge-transfer (LMCT). As is well-known, free H3CTC ligand exhibits a fluorescent emission peak at 570 nm. Compared with free H3CTC ligand, compound 1 exhibits a blue-shift emission peak. And the other emission peaks, 494.5, 547, 585.5, and 622.5 nm, correspond to the characteristic emission peak of terbium ion, which is the transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, and 3). In the range of 520−650 nm which is the emission range of H3CTC ligand, the emission peaks at 573nm, 572nm, 572nm, and 562nm of compounds 2−5 are attributed to the emission of H3CTC ligand. The result reveals that the compounds 1−5 will be anticipated as the potential fluorescent material.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1-5 are shown in Figure . The emission group of compound 1 is in the range of 460-660 nm (λex = 235 nm), which can be attributed to the terbium ion, corresponding to 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, and 3), and free H3CTC ligand, respectively. The emission peak at 523 nm of compound 1 should be related to the emission of ligand-to-metal-charge-transfer (LMCT). As is well-known, free H3CTC ligand exhibits a fluorescent emission peak at 570 nm. Compared with free H3CTC ligand, compound 1 exhibits a blue-shift emission peak. And the other emission peaks, 494.5, 547, 585.5, and 622.5 nm, correspond to the characteristic emission peak of terbium ion, which is the transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, and 3). In the range of 520-650 nm which is the emission range of H3CTC ligand, the emission peaks at 573nm, 572nm, 572nm, and 562nm of compounds 2-5 are attributed to the emission of H3CTC ligand. The result reveals that the compounds 1-5 will be anticipated as the potential fluorescent material.

elements.content: (a) Photoluminescence spectrum of compound 1 (excitation spectrum (λem = 547 nm), black; emission spectrum (λex = 235 nm), red), (b) photoluminescence spectrum of compound 2 (excitation spectrum (λem = 573 nm), black; emission spectrum (λex = 390 nm), red), (c) photoluminescence spectrum of compound 3 (excitation spectrum (λem = 572 nm), black; emission spectrum (λex = 395 nm), red), (d) photoluminescence spectrum of compound 4 (excitation spectrum (λem = 572 nm), black; emission spectrum (λex = 396 nm), red), (e) photoluminescence spectrum of compound 1 (excitation spectrum (λem = 562 nm), black; emission spectrum (λex = 397 nm), red).

elements.content: The adsorption isotherms of compounds 1−5 for H2O and CH3OH were measured at room temperature (298 K). In order to remove the guest and free molecules, all of the compounds 1−5 were evacuated under reduced pressure (1 × 10−5 Torr) until no weight of sample is lost at 80 °C. As shown at Figure , type I behavior is observed for the H2O and CH3OH adsorption isotherms. At saturation, the amounts of H2O adsorbed are 105.07 mg/g, 113.28 mg/g, 106.21 mg/g, 119.36 mg/g, and 117.93 mg/g for compounds 1−5, respectively, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 13, 14, 13, 15, and 15 water molecules per unit cell. For CH3OH, the adsorbed amounts are 98.62 mg/g, 97.16 mg/g, 99.01 mg/g, 95.24 mg/g, and 94.01 mg/g, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about seven methanol molecules per unit cell of the compound 1−5.
elements.clean_text:
Water and Methanol Adsorption Properties

The adsorption isotherms of compounds 1-5 for H2O and CH3OH were measured at room temperature (298 K). In order to remove the guest and free molecules, all of the compounds 1-5 were evacuated under reduced pressure (1 × 10-5 Torr) until no weight of sample is lost at 80 °C. As shown at Figure , type I behavior is observed for the H2O and CH3OH adsorption isotherms. At saturation, the amounts of H2O adsorbed are 105.07 mg/g, 113.28 mg/g, 106.21 mg/g, 119.36 mg/g, and 117.93 mg/g for compounds 1-5, respectively, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 13, 14, 13, 15, and 15 water molecules per unit cell. For CH3OH, the adsorbed amounts are 98.62 mg/g, 97.16 mg/g, 99.01 mg/g, 95.24 mg/g, and 94.01 mg/g, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about seven methanol molecules per unit cell of the compound 1-5.

elements.content: Water and methanol adsorption isotherms for compounds 1−5 (H2O, (a); methanol, (b)).
elements.clean_text: 5  Water and methanol adsorption isotherms for compounds 1-5 (H2O, (a); methanol, (b)).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of compound 1 indicates that the first weight loss of 16.54% from 35 to 220 °C is attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.44%), and the second weight loss of 14.96% between 220 and 400 °C is attributed to the dissociation of coordinated DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.44%). When the temperature is above 400 °C, the compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 32.87% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.72%) of the Tb and O components, Tb4O7, PXRD patterns, which is the same as the standard one.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis of compound 1 indicates that the first weight loss of 16.54% from 35 to 220 °C is attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.44%), and the second weight loss of 14.96% between 220 and 400 °C is attributed to the dissociation of coordinated DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.44%). When the temperature is above 400 °C, the compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 32.87% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.72%) of the Tb and O components, Tb4O7, PXRD patterns, which is the same as the standard one.

elements.content: For compounds 2, 3, and 4, the first weight losses of 16.82% (35−290 °C), 17.24% (35−290 °C), and 16.59% (35−310 °C) are attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.33%, 16.26%, and 16.19%), and when the temperatures are above 400, 380, and 420 °C respectively, compounds 2, 3, and 4 decompose and the remaining weight of 34.13%, 34.66%, and 34.27% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.43%, 33.72%, and 33.99%) of the M (M = Dy, Ho, Er) and O components, M2O3 ((M = Dy, Ho, Er). 16.91% weight loss of compound 5 from 35 to 250 °C is attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%), and the second weight loss of 15.69% between 250 and 400 °C is attributed to the dissociation of coordinated DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%). When the temperature is above 400 °C, compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 34.86% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.19%) of the Tm and O components, Tm2O3. All of remaining products are characterized by PXRD patterns.
elements.clean_text: For compounds 2, 3, and 4, the first weight losses of 16.82% (35-290 °C), 17.24% (35-290 °C), and 16.59% (35-310 °C) are attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.33%, 16.26%, and 16.19%), and when the temperatures are above 400, 380, and 420 °C respectively, compounds 2, 3, and 4 decompose and the remaining weight of 34.13%, 34.66%, and 34.27% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.43%, 33.72%, and 33.99%) of the M (M = Dy, Ho, Er) and O components, M2O3 ((M = Dy, Ho, Er). 16.91% weight loss of compound 5 from 35 to 250 °C is attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%), and the second weight loss of 15.69% between 250 and 400 °C is attributed to the dissociation of coordinated DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%). When the temperature is above 400 °C, compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 34.86% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.19%) of the Tm and O components, Tm2O3. All of remaining products are characterized by PXRD patterns.

elements.content: A series of 3-D lanthanide coordination compounds, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4) and Tm (5)), have been synthesized first under mild conditions. To study deeply the structure of these compounds, each dinuclear metal center is regarded as a six-connected node and the CTC ligand can be considered as an organic three-connected node. By linking these six-connected nodes and three-connected nodes, the rutile topology is shown with a vertex symbol of (4·4·4·4·64·64). Those dinuclear metal centers are interconnected through CTC ligands to generate approximately 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels along the [100] direction and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels along the [011] and [01̅1] direction, respectively. In addition, compound 1 exhibits both fluorescence property and substantial adsorption behaviors. It is believed that these compounds with the 3-D interconnecting pores and fluorescent and adsorption properties could be anticipated as multifunctional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of 3-D lanthanide coordination compounds, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4) and Tm (5)), have been synthesized first under mild conditions. To study deeply the structure of these compounds, each dinuclear metal center is regarded as a six-connected node and the CTC ligand can be considered as an organic three-connected node. By linking these six-connected nodes and three-connected nodes, the rutile topology is shown with a vertex symbol of (4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅64⋅64). Those dinuclear metal centers are interconnected through CTC ligands to generate approximately 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels along the [100] direction and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels along the [011] and [01̅1] direction, respectively. In addition, compound 1 exhibits both fluorescence property and substantial adsorption behaviors. It is believed that these compounds with the 3-D interconnecting pores and fluorescent and adsorption properties could be anticipated as multifunctional materials.

elements.content: IR spectrum, powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and crystallographic information file (CIF) of 1, thermogravimetric analysis, selected bond angles and powder X-ray diffraction patterns for remaining products of 1−5. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: IR spectrum, powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and crystallographic information file (CIF) of 1, thermogravimetric analysis, selected bond angles and powder X-ray diffraction patterns for remaining products of 1-5. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content: Because of the same process of preparing compounds 1−5, the compound 1 is described in detail. A DMF (10 mL) and H2O (5 mL) mixed-solution containing Tb(NO3)3·nH2O (50 mg, 0.12 mmol) and H3CTC (10 mg, 0.05 mmol) was placed in a 20 mL test tube, and 0.5 mL of DMF solution containing triethylamine (0.05 mL) was put in a small vial. The vial was sealed with a stopper which had been pierced with a pinprick to allow slow diffusion of the contents. This vial was placed in the larger test tube, and then the test tube was left at 4 °C for 14 days and at room temperature for 35 days, and colorless crystals of compound 1 were collected (yield: 61% base on Tb). If the test tube was not left at 4 °C before removing it to room temperature, hardly any crystals formed. Main IR absorption bands (cm−1): 3427s, 2930w, 2868w, 1658m, 1595m, 1539s, 1427s, 1113m, 1061m, 783m, 681s, 581m. For compounds 2−5, yield: 71%, 68%, 63%, and 69%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Tb(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O) (1)

Because of the same process of preparing compounds 1-5, the compound 1 is described in detail. A DMF (10 mL) and H2O (5 mL) mixed-solution containing Tb(NO3)3⋅nH2O (50 mg, 0.12 mmol) and H3CTC (10 mg, 0.05 mmol) was placed in a 20 mL test tube, and 0.5 mL of DMF solution containing triethylamine (0.05 mL) was put in a small vial. The vial was sealed with a stopper which had been pierced with a pinprick to allow slow diffusion of the contents. This vial was placed in the larger test tube, and then the test tube was left at 4 °C for 14 days and at room temperature for 35 days, and colorless crystals of compound 1 were collected (yield: 61% base on Tb). If the test tube was not left at 4 °C before removing it to room temperature, hardly any crystals formed. Main IR absorption bands (cm-1): 3427s, 2930w, 2868w, 1658m, 1595m, 1539s, 1427s, 1113m, 1061m, 783m, 681s, 581m. For compounds 2-5, yield: 71%, 68%, 63%, and 69%.

processes.temperature: 4 °C for 14 days and room temperature for 35 days

cln_elements.content:
A series of three-dimensional lanthanide coordination compounds with rutile topology, M(CTC)(DMF)(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O) (M = Tb (1), Dy (2), Ho (3), Er (4), and Tm (5), CTC = cis,cis-1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide), have been synthesized under mild conditions. They are isomorphous and crystallize in monoclinic symmetry with space group P21/n. The structure can be considered to be built up from metallic 6-connected and organic 3-connected building units with vertex symbol (4·4·4·4·64·64). These lanthanide coordination compounds possess 10.4 × 10.1 Å2 channels along the [100] direction, and 7.7 × 7.7 Å2 channels along the [011] and [01̅1] direction, respectively. The fluorescent, water, and methanol adsorption properties of these compounds are studied, and the results reveal that they could be potentially utilized as multifunctional materials.

Photoluminescent Properties

The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1−5 are shown in Figure . The emission group of compound 1 is in the range of 460−660 nm (λex = 235 nm), which can be attributed to the terbium ion, corresponding to 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, and 3), and free H3CTC ligand, respectively. The emission peak at 523 nm of compound 1 should be related to the emission of ligand-to-metal-charge-transfer (LMCT). As is well-known, free H3CTC ligand exhibits a fluorescent emission peak at 570 nm. Compared with free H3CTC ligand, compound 1 exhibits a blue-shift emission peak. And the other emission peaks, 494.5, 547, 585.5, and 622.5 nm, correspond to the characteristic emission peak of terbium ion, which is the transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, and 3). In the range of 520−650 nm which is the emission range of H3CTC ligand, the emission peaks at 573nm, 572nm, 572nm, and 562nm of compounds 2−5 are attributed to the emission of H3CTC ligand. The result reveals that the compounds 1−5 will be anticipated as the potential fluorescent material.

Water and Methanol Adsorption Properties

The adsorption isotherms of compounds 1−5 for H2O and CH3OH were measured at room temperature (298 K). In order to remove the guest and free molecules, all of the compounds 1−5 were evacuated under reduced pressure (1 × 10−5 Torr) until no weight of sample is lost at 80 °C. As shown at Figure , type I behavior is observed for the H2O and CH3OH adsorption isotherms. At saturation, the amounts of H2O adsorbed are 105.07 mg/g, 113.28 mg/g, 106.21 mg/g, 119.36 mg/g, and 117.93 mg/g for compounds 1−5, respectively, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 13, 14, 13, 15, and 15 water molecules per unit cell. For CH3OH, the adsorbed amounts are 98.62 mg/g, 97.16 mg/g, 99.01 mg/g, 95.24 mg/g, and 94.01 mg/g, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about seven methanol molecules per unit cell of the compound 1−5.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis of compound 1 indicates that the first weight loss of 16.54% from 35 to 220 °C is attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.44%), and the second weight loss of 14.96% between 220 and 400 °C is attributed to the dissociation of coordinated DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.44%). When the temperature is above 400 °C, the compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 32.87% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.72%) of the Tb and O components, Tb4O7, PXRD patterns, which is the same as the standard one.

For compounds 2, 3, and 4, the first weight losses of 16.82% (35−290 °C), 17.24% (35−290 °C), and 16.59% (35−310 °C) are attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.33%, 16.26%, and 16.19%), and when the temperatures are above 400, 380, and 420 °C respectively, compounds 2, 3, and 4 decompose and the remaining weight of 34.13%, 34.66%, and 34.27% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.43%, 33.72%, and 33.99%) of the M (M = Dy, Ho, Er) and O components, M2O3 ((M = Dy, Ho, Er). 16.91% weight loss of compound 5 from 35 to 250 °C is attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%), and the second weight loss of 15.69% between 250 and 400 °C is attributed to the dissociation of coordinated DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%). When the temperature is above 400 °C, compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 34.86% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.19%) of the Tm and O components, Tm2O3. All of remaining products are characterized by PXRD patterns.

They are isomorphous and crystallize in monoclinic symmetry with space group P21/n. And the other emission peaks, 494.5, 547, 585.5, and 622.5 nm, correspond to the characteristic emission peak of terbium ion, which is the transition of 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4, and 3). When the temperature is above 400 °C, the compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 32.87% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.72%) of the Tb and O components, Tb4O7, PXRD patterns, which is the same as the standard one.

For compounds 2, 3, and 4, the first weight losses of 16.82% (35-290 °C), 17.24% (35-290 °C), and 16.59% (35-310 °C) are attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.33%, 16.26%, and 16.19%), and when the temperatures are above 400, 380, and 420 °C respectively, compounds 2, 3, and 4 decompose and the remaining weight of 34.13%, 34.66%, and 34.27% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.43%, 33.72%, and 33.99%) of the M (M = Dy, Ho, Er) and O components, M2O3 ((M = Dy, Ho, Er). 16.91% weight loss of compound 5 from 35 to 250 °C is attributed to the dissociation of free DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%), and the second weight loss of 15.69% between 250 and 400 °C is attributed to the dissociation of coordinated DMF and H2O molecules (calculated: 16.15%). When the temperature is above 400 °C, compound 1 decomposes and the remaining weight of 34.86% corresponds to the percentage (calculated: 33.19%) of the Tm and O components, Tm2O3. All of remaining products are characterized by PXRD patterns.

metadata.title:
A Series of Three-Dimensional Lanthanide Coordination Compounds with the Rutile Topology
3D Lanthanide Coordination Compounds
